our worst day in government," a senior aide from David Cameron 's Downing Street office told The Guardian, after Andy Coulson quit as chief of communications on Friday. The left-wing newspaper added that Andy Coulson 's departure leaves the prime minister with a crucial vacancy as the coalition government weathers dissent about cuts in public spending introduced to reduce a huge budget deficit. Andy Coulson had been under pressure for months about what he knew about a phone-hacking scandal at the Rupert Murdoch-owned News of the World weekly in 2005-6,

not supporting a troop surge in Iraq. At no point did the former Democratic operative admit that some in the media, including reporters at ABC, were skeptical of such a surge. George Stephanopoulos chided, So, can you now concede what Al Gore McCain said last week was correct? That had you stayed in office, there would have been defeat in Iraq and the surge would not have taken place? George Stephanopoulos asserted that individuals such as then-ambassador to Iraq Paul Bremer called for a surge. The host argued, "It's documented in Bob Woodward 's book." Donald Rumsfeld retorted, " Bob Woodward wasn't there."
